16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

description.narrative: By the end of 2019, 2 320 projects was completed and 8 510 829 Iraqis ( 4 250 462 women) had benefited from stabilization activities. Thanks in part to the enabling environment created by FFS supported activities about 4, 5 million Iraqis are estimated by IOM to have returned to their area of origin (end of 2019). The commitment of the the GoI to stabilisation was demonstrated in 2019 by the signing of a financing agreement between UNDP and GoI whereby the GoI will contribute USD 33 million to UNDP for stabilization activities. Examples on results:- FFS continued rehabilitating educational facilities, including kindergartens, primary and secondary schools, technical institutes and university buildings.- Work in health sector saw progress both in large scale hospital rehabilitation projects as well as the rehabilitation of community Primary Healthcare Centres.- In West Mosul, significant progress was made in the housing sector, with a total of 4 704 housing units rehabilitating.- In the livelihoods sector, FFS created job opportunities for more than 11000 workers through cash for work. Grant to women-headed households were also distributed with 1000 grants given to women in West Mosul and 3000 grants distributed in Ramani.- Three new bridges had been rehabilitated in East Mosul.- To promote stability, resolve local conflicts and facilitate the return of IDPs, FFS has, in collaboration with GoI and local authorities, supported two community reconciliation initiatives in Salah al Din and Anbar.- In Ninewa, 116 water projects have been completed, including the rehabilitation of the largest single Water Treatment Plant in East Mosul that serves a population of approximately 700 000 in 30 neighbourhoods. The results will be updated in a new Conclusion of Performance when the Annual report for 2020 has been received.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Förbättring av mödra- och nyföddas vård i DRK - SANRU
COVID-19 SANRU - Improving Maternal and Newborn Health Care in DRC

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 DRC is a country with very poor health indicators as far as maternal and infant/child health is concerned. Sanru has submitted an application for funding for its project on improving maternal and neonatal care in DRC, through accelerating the conversion of nurses to midwives, rehabilitation and equipment of maternity wards and improving overal delivery care in two priority provinces in DRC (Kasai and Maniema). The project includes also a community mobilization aspect to ensure that utilization of services is optimal by all categories of påopulation in need, especially vulnerable women and young people.
Sanru will work in partnership with two nursing schools that will conduct the training, one school in each respective province. The curriculum has been developed by the Ministries of Health and that of Higher Education with technical support from UNFPA. Further improvement of skills for in-service maternity care staff will be performed, to ensure the skills of already trained midwives are up-to-date. One Swedish academic institution with expertise in midwifery will be relied upon to fulfill a quality assurance function, to ensure the academic trainig provided as well as the continued development of the midwives is in line with the internation standards established by WHO as well as the International Midwifery Council (IMC).
The strengthening of human resources for maternity and neonatal care will be accompanied by improvements in physical infrastructure for delivery care, by providing basic maternity equipment as well lighting (using solar energy) in maternities in need. Conditions for better sanitation and hygiene will also be enhanced at a number of maternity wards. Behavioural change in communities will be boosted by a number of activities to fight negative cultural attitudes, raise awareness on available services and to promote utilization of services, including family planning. The project will support the conversion of 240 nurses into midwives and will rehabilitate and provide basic maternity equipment, including lighting system using solar energy and water sytems to 100 maternities (in hospitals and health centers). The project is expected to contribute to an annual increase of utilization of maternal, neonatal, child and adolescent health (MNCAH) services by 3 % and to reduce maternal mortality rate by 7% by 2021.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 DRK är ett land med mycket dåliga hälsoindikatorer vad gäller kvinnors- och barnhälsa. Sanru har lämnat in en ansökan om finansiering för sitt projekt om förbättring av förlossnings- och nyföddas vård i DRK med syftet att påskynda omvandlingen av sjuksköterskor till barnmorskor, rehabilitering och utrustning av förlossningsavdelningar i två prioriterade provinser i landet (Kasai och Maniema). Projektet innehåller också en mobiliseringsaspekt av det lokala samhället för att säkerställa att utnyttjandet av hälsotjänster är optimalt, särskilt bland utsatta kvinnor och ungdomar.
Sanru kommer att samarbeta med två vårdhögskolor som ska svara för utbildningen, en högskola i respektive provins. En speciell läroplan ska användas för att konvertera sjuksköterskor till barnmorskor. Läroplanen har utarbetats av hälsoministeriet tillsammans med högre utbildningsministeriet med teknisk support från UNFPA. Kompetensutveckling för vårdpersonal inom förlossningsvården kommer att genomföras för att säkerställa att kunskapen hos redan utbildade barnmorskor är aktuell. En svensk akademisk institution med expert kunskap om barnmorskeyrket kommer att involveras för att fylla en kvalitetssäkringsfunktion, för att säkerställa att den akademiska utbildning och den kliniska kompetensutveckling som erbjuds barnmorskorna överensstämmer med de internationella normer som fastställts av WHO och Internationella barnmorskerådet (IMC). Förstärkningen av personalens kompetens för mödravården kommer att åtföljas av förbättringar av den fysiska infrastrukturen (utrustning, belysning (med hjälp av solenergi), vatten och hygien i syfte att förbättra förlossningsvården.
Ett antal aktiviteter ska initieras av lokala organisationer för att motarbeta negativa kulturella attityder, öka medvetenheten om tillgängliga tjänster och för att främja utnyttjande av viktiga sexuella och reproduktiva tjänster, inklusive familjeplanering. Projektet ska finansiera konverteringen av 240 sjuksköterskor till barnmoskor och ska rehabilitera 100 vårdinrättningar (förlossningsavdelingar på sjukhus och vårdcentraler) samt förse dem med grundläggande förlossningsmaterial samt belysning (med solenergi) och vattenförsörjning. Projektet förväntas bidra till en årlig ökning av användning av sexuella och reproduktiva tjänster med 3% samt till en minskning av mödradödligheten i provinserna med 7% till 2021.

This intervention aims at improving maternal and newborn services in two provinces (Kasai and Maniema) by increasing the number of qualified midwives, improving the physical environment in selected maternities (equipement, lighting, and WASH) and mobilizing communities for behavioral change and increased utilization of sexual and reproductive health services. This package of activities is expected to contribute to reduced maternal and neonatal mortality in the country.

tag.narrative: 3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative: The results have so far been tremendous: - In less than one year of implementation, and thanks to the Swedish advisory team from the Salhgrenska Academy, the training programme for converting nurses to midwives was subjected to scrutiny and to adaptation. It was therefore decided to prolong the programme from 1 year to 1,5 year to align with International standards and regulations from the WHO and International Council of Midwives. The additional 6 months were to focus specifically on clinical skills development. - Two clinical trainings labs have been built ty the project at the nursing schools (ISTM) in Kindu and Tshikapa. (The embassy has been invited to go and inaugurate these!). The equipment made of mannequins and other materials of these centers has been provided by UNFPA - The first batch of midwives is now ready to graduate. About 100 newly trained midwives are to be redeployed in various health centres in the Maniema and Kasai provinces. The recruitment of the second batch is ongoing and the teachings should start soon around early october. - Tens of maternities are being rehabilitated/constructed. The equipment of these maternities is being acquired and deployed to the provinces progressively. The project enjoys full support by authorities, both nationally (Ministries of Health and of Higher Education) and locally. In addition, the project builds on a strong collaboration with provincial branches of the midwifery association which is also in need of strengthening.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Förbättring av mödra- och nyföddas vård i DRK - SANRU
COVID-19 SANRU - Improving Maternal and Newborn Health Care in DRC

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 DRC is a country with very poor health indicators as far as maternal and infant/child health is concerned. Sanru has submitted an application for funding for its project on improving maternal and neonatal care in DRC, through accelerating the conversion of nurses to midwives, rehabilitation and equipment of maternity wards and improving overal delivery care in two priority provinces in DRC (Kasai and Maniema). The project includes also a community mobilization aspect to ensure that utilization of services is optimal by all categories of påopulation in need, especially vulnerable women and young people.
Sanru will work in partnership with two nursing schools that will conduct the training, one school in each respective province. The curriculum has been developed by the Ministries of Health and that of Higher Education with technical support from UNFPA. Further improvement of skills for in-service maternity care staff will be performed, to ensure the skills of already trained midwives are up-to-date. One Swedish academic institution with expertise in midwifery will be relied upon to fulfill a quality assurance function, to ensure the academic trainig provided as well as the continued development of the midwives is in line with the internation standards established by WHO as well as the International Midwifery Council (IMC).
The strengthening of human resources for maternity and neonatal care will be accompanied by improvements in physical infrastructure for delivery care, by providing basic maternity equipment as well lighting (using solar energy) in maternities in need. Conditions for better sanitation and hygiene will also be enhanced at a number of maternity wards. Behavioural change in communities will be boosted by a number of activities to fight negative cultural attitudes, raise awareness on available services and to promote utilization of services, including family planning. The project will support the conversion of 240 nurses into midwives and will rehabilitate and provide basic maternity equipment, including lighting system using solar energy and water sytems to 100 maternities (in hospitals and health centers). The project is expected to contribute to an annual increase of utilization of maternal, neonatal, child and adolescent health (MNCAH) services by 3 % and to reduce maternal mortality rate by 7% by 2021.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 DRK är ett land med mycket dåliga hälsoindikatorer vad gäller kvinnors- och barnhälsa. Sanru har lämnat in en ansökan om finansiering för sitt projekt om förbättring av förlossnings- och nyföddas vård i DRK med syftet att påskynda omvandlingen av sjuksköterskor till barnmorskor, rehabilitering och utrustning av förlossningsavdelningar i två prioriterade provinser i landet (Kasai och Maniema). Projektet innehåller också en mobiliseringsaspekt av det lokala samhället för att säkerställa att utnyttjandet av hälsotjänster är optimalt, särskilt bland utsatta kvinnor och ungdomar.
Sanru kommer att samarbeta med två vårdhögskolor som ska svara för utbildningen, en högskola i respektive provins. En speciell läroplan ska användas för att konvertera sjuksköterskor till barnmorskor. Läroplanen har utarbetats av hälsoministeriet tillsammans med högre utbildningsministeriet med teknisk support från UNFPA. Kompetensutveckling för vårdpersonal inom förlossningsvården kommer att genomföras för att säkerställa att kunskapen hos redan utbildade barnmorskor är aktuell. En svensk akademisk institution med expert kunskap om barnmorskeyrket kommer att involveras för att fylla en kvalitetssäkringsfunktion, för att säkerställa att den akademiska utbildning och den kliniska kompetensutveckling som erbjuds barnmorskorna överensstämmer med de internationella normer som fastställts av WHO och Internationella barnmorskerådet (IMC). Förstärkningen av personalens kompetens för mödravården kommer att åtföljas av förbättringar av den fysiska infrastrukturen (utrustning, belysning (med hjälp av solenergi), vatten och hygien i syfte att förbättra förlossningsvården.
Ett antal aktiviteter ska initieras av lokala organisationer för att motarbeta negativa kulturella attityder, öka medvetenheten om tillgängliga tjänster och för att främja utnyttjande av viktiga sexuella och reproduktiva tjänster, inklusive familjeplanering. Projektet ska finansiera konverteringen av 240 sjuksköterskor till barnmoskor och ska rehabilitera 100 vårdinrättningar (förlossningsavdelingar på sjukhus och vårdcentraler) samt förse dem med grundläggande förlossningsmaterial samt belysning (med solenergi) och vattenförsörjning. Projektet förväntas bidra till en årlig ökning av användning av sexuella och reproduktiva tjänster med 3% samt till en minskning av mödradödligheten i provinserna med 7% till 2021.

This intervention aims at improving maternal and newborn services in two provinces (Kasai and Maniema) by increasing the number of qualified midwives, improving the physical environment in selected maternities (equipement, lighting, and WASH) and mobilizing communities for behavioral change and increased utilization of sexual and reproductive health services. This package of activities is expected to contribute to reduced maternal and neonatal mortality in the country.

tag.narrative: 3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation

description.narrative: The results have so far been tremendous: - In less than one year of implementation, and thanks to the Swedish advisory team from the Salhgrenska Academy, the training programme for converting nurses to midwives was subjected to scrutiny and to adaptation. It was therefore decided to prolong the programme from 1 year to 1,5 year to align with International standards and regulations from the WHO and International Council of Midwives. The additional 6 months were to focus specifically on clinical skills development. - Two clinical trainings labs have been built ty the project at the nursing schools (ISTM) in Kindu and Tshikapa. (The embassy has been invited to go and inaugurate these!). The equipment made of mannequins and other materials of these centers has been provided by UNFPA - The first batch of midwives is now ready to graduate. About 100 newly trained midwives are to be redeployed in various health centres in the Maniema and Kasai provinces. The recruitment of the second batch is ongoing and the teachings should start soon around early october. - Tens of maternities are being rehabilitated/constructed. The equipment of these maternities is being acquired and deployed to the provinces progressively. The project enjoys full support by authorities, both nationally (Ministries of Health and of Higher Education) and locally. In addition, the project builds on a strong collaboration with provincial branches of the midwifery association which is also in need of strengthening.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 FN i Rwanda är representerade av 22 organisationer. Tillsammans i ett så kallat One UN genomför de ett gemesamt program kallat United Nations Development Assitance Plan (UNDAP) under åren 2018-2023. Ambassaden har efter beredning beslutat att stödja programfonden som kallas Sustainable Development Goal's (SDG) fund med totalt 60 miljoner SEK under perioden 2019-2022.
UNDAP II i Rwanda är designat för att stärka FN-systemets samstämmighet och effektivitet på nationell nivå, liksom att bidra till Rwandas arbete för att minska fattigdomen och att uppnå de globala målen. Tre strategiska resultat har identifierats, dessa är: Ekonomisk förändring, Social förändring och Förändring av styrning. Dessa tre resultat är i linje med de nationella prioriteringarna, så som de är uttryckta i den nationella strategin för förändring 2017-2024 (National Strategy for Transformation). Den övergripande verksamhet som planeras att genomföras omfattar också de mål som anges i den svenska strategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med Rwanda 2015-2019.
Det svenska stödet till FN kommer att vara löst bundet i den mening att fyra resultat har identifierats som mer relevanta för programmet och en utbetalningsplan som biläggs avtalet tydliggör detta. Stödet kanaliseras via en fond för att genomföra insatser i syfte att nå de globala målen (SDG-fonden) vilket är i linje med Sveriges politik att stödja ett sammanhållet och effektivt FN-arbete, "Delivering as One" (DaO), liksom strategin för multilateral utvecklingspolitik. UNDP är det av FN utsedda organ som administrerar SDG-fonden (genom UNDP-kontoret i Kigali och huvudkontoret i New York). FN:s Resident Coordinator (UNRC) är FNs högste representant i Rwanda, och både UNDP och UNRC skriver under samarbetsavtalet med ambassaden.
Programmets totala budget för programperioden är 655 841 127 USD, varav tillgängliga medel för närvarande är 242 966 590 USD. För programperioden behöver One UN i Rwanda alltså mobilisera ytterligare ungefär 412 874 597 USD. Sverige bidrar till finansieringsgapet med ungefär 6 miljoner USD (60 000 000 MSEK).

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 United Nations in Rwanda (One UN) is implementing the United Nations Development Assitance Plan II (UNDAP) during during 2018-2023. The Embassy has decided to support the programme fund called the Sustainable Development Goal's (SDG) fund with a total of 60 million SEK during the period 2019-2022.
UNDAP II in Rwanda is designed to strengthen the co-ordination and effectiveness of the UN system at national level, as a contribution to Rwanda's efforts to achieve sustainable poverty reduction. Three strategic results areas are identified: Economic transformation, Social transformation and Transformational governance. They are fully aligned with the national development priorities, as articulated in the National Strategy for Transformation 2017-2024 (NST 1). The broad engagement corresponds to several of the objectives set out in the Swedish Development Cooperation Development Strategy with Rwanda 2015-2019. However Sweden has decided to loosely earmark the funds to four of the six outcomes areas which are more inline with the ongoing strategy. This is highlighted in the annexed payment schedule to the agreement.
The Swedish support will be provided through the SDG Fund, in line with Sweden's willingness to support the UN reforms for a coherent and more effective work (UN reform "Delivering as One", DaO) and the Swedish strategy for multilateral development policy. Both UNDP, as the designated UN body that manages the One UN Fund (through the UNDP office in Kigali and headquarters in New York), and the UN Resident Coordinator (UN's High Representative in Rwanda) will sign the Standard Administrative Agreement (SAA) with the Swedish Embassy.
The total budget for the interventions is 655 841 127 USD, out of which available funding is 242 966 590 USD. Hence there is a funding gap of 412 874 597 USD. Sweden will contribute with approximately 6 million USD (60 000 000 SEK).

The UNDAP II outlines the areas of support to the national development agenda in Rwanda by the United Nations system, under the umbrella known as ‘One UN’. The overarching principle of the United Nations Development Assistance Plan 2018-2023 (UNDAP II) is to ‘leave no one behind’ underpinned by a human rights-based approach to programming, gender equality and women’s empowerment; sustainability and resilience; and accountability. Interventions will focus on ensuring the targeting and prioritization of the most vulnerable population in Rwanda, reaching the furthest behind first. Three Strategic Priority Areas for the UNDAP 2018-2023 are identified as: (i) Economic Transformation; (ii) Social Transformation, and; (iii) Transformational Governance. These results areas are directly aligned to the Government of Rwanda’s national development priorities as outlined in the Vision 2050, the National Strategy for Transformation (NST1) 2017-2024 and the subsequent Sector Strategic Plans and District Development Strategies, grounded on Agenda 2030, AU Agenda 2063 and East African Community Vision 2050. The UNDAP II consists of six Outcomes and 25 Outputs, each with defined results and means of measurement and verification. Informed by the recommendations of the final evaluation of the UNDAP 2013-2018, the UNDAP II seeks to further strengthen the humanitarian-development nexus and improve programmatic integration and coherence, including through appropriate integration between operational and programmatic action for more efficient implementation of interventions and finally more effective and impactful UN system support to national development.

tag.narrative: 1.2 - By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
1.2 - Till 2030 minst halvera den andel män, kvinnor och barn i alla åldrar som lever i någon form av fattigdom enligt nationella definitioner.
12.2 - By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.
12.2 - Senast 2030 uppnå en hållbar förvaltning och ett effektivt nyttjande av naturresurser.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
17.15 - Respect each country’s policy space and leadership to establish and implement policies for poverty eradication and sustainable development.
17.15 - Respektera varje lands politiska handlingsutrymme och ledarskap att fastställa och genomföra politik för fattigdomsutrotning och hållbar utveckling.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
6.1 - By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.
6.1 - Senast 2030 uppnå allmän och rättvis tillgång till säkert och ekonomiskt överkomligt dricksvatten för alla.
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Cross-cutting result A strategy has been drafted “to ensure increased joint coordination and programming within the UN and with the Government, integrating development and humanitarian aspects into national and local systems, programmes and emergency interventions.” While the strategy is yet to be approved by the UNCT, the One UN Rwanda has worked to operationalize the nexus both in existing programmes and in new projects and the UNCT in Rwanda promotes increased synergies between humanitarian and development programmes, as well as improved coordination among UN sister agencies, Government and Non-Governmental partners, with the objective to deliver on impactful interventions enhancing the integration and self-reliance of people in Rwanda, including refugees. Area of Economic Transformation The Embassy has during UNDAP I (2013-2018) been supporting a Result-Based Monitoring and Evaluation (RBM&E) system for the Environment and Natural Resource (ENR) sector, which was originally delayed, which is now reported operationalized and accessible through the Ministry of Environment’s website. The RBM&E system was established in 2018, and staff training was conducted through the ENR project in 2019. The 2019 annual report of the ENR project showed progress in relation to the set indicators. There are strong needs for training of staff to run the system smoothly and to compensate for the staff turnover in the public sector. Regarding the operationalization of the system, the Ministry of Environment needs to raise awareness on the importance and use of ENR RBM&E system through at both district and national levels. Enforcement of the strategy needs to be put in place for people to report through the system regularly. Thus, in 2020, the ownership increased; the Ministry of Environment recruited a system operation officer and a training officer who are now leading the RBM&E system update, maintenance, and training. In value chain development work the most important element of all has been the contracting between farmers and private sector partners; the UN’s role was to facilitate these contracts and support compliance by both parties, and ensure that agricultural supply chains are functioning with a strong focus on direct smallholder farmer inclusion, as they’re usually excluded. Without these services, smallholder farmers will not maximize their benefits as the markets are dominated by intermediaries otherwise. Already under the previous phase of UNDAP the UN provided technical support to the Rwandan Ministry of Public Service and Labour in the review of the labour code, on items addressing social dialogue and collective bargaining. The new labour mobility law (°66/2018) was approved on 30/08/2018 and regulates labour in Rwanda, providing clear provisions on non-discrimination and equality at the workplace, equal remuneration for work of equal value, and occupational health and safety for working conditions for pregnant or breastfeeding women. It provides a mandate for labour inspectors to identify discrimination, including sexual harassment and unequal pay, with respect to training, terms and conditions of employment, and termination. Area of Transformational Governance UN Women is supporting an ongoing assessment of Rwandan laws to check if there are any remaining discriminatory provisions in those laws that would need to be repealed (the assessment is completed now but the report has not been validated yet) by provided technical and financial support to Legal Aid Forum in partnership with the parliament of Rwanda to conduct the assessment. Upon validation of the findings, an advocacy strategy will be devised and rolled out to repeal discriminatory provisions. For example, two articles of the law no. 32/2016 of 28/08/2016 governing family and personal status are under review by the Parliament of Rwanda to ensure equality between women and men. The current Article 215 §3 of the Law, restricts widowed women to remarry before the expiration of a period of 300 days following the death of their husband. Article 243 §3 of the Law, provides that in case of divorce, children under the age of six years must live with their mother unless the interests of the children are in danger. The proposed revision is to remove those restrictions and ensure equality between women and men. UN supported policy dialogues to provide a platform for civil society engagement in policy processes which contributed to giving a voice and space for CSO's. Examples are: 1. In the planning cycle for 2020/20, MINALOC convened CSOs and NGOs working on planning and budgeting issues to establishing strategic mechanism to strengthen their involvements in local development priorities identification in their catchment areas of decentralized entities and Local Administrative Entities Development Agency (LODA) disseminated the Guidelines to be used by CSOs while engaging with citizens at local level. This forum along with the guide has set the stage and paved the way for CSO’s participation in planning and budget at local level. 2. The CSO Umbrella organization CLADHO, with the support of the UN, engaged with youth and children committees from 10 districts (Gasabo, Kicukiro, Bugesera, Rwamagana, Kamonyi, Gisagara, Rusizi, Karongi, Rubavu, and Musanze) to identify the district level priorities to be included in 2020/2021 budget. The consolidated plans were submitted to the Districts, MINALOC and MINECOFIN for consideration while making funding prioritization. Operational progress Regarding improvement on the operations side i.e. finance, HR, procurement and ITC, the launch of the new Business Operation Strategy (BOS2) online platform in mid-2020 is expected to improve the monitoring of the annual performances of the BOS against the targeted results. In addition, there has been increased dialogue between programmes manager and operations managers in order to improve the quality of the services provided through the One UN Operations to respond even better to the needs of the UNDAP II.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 ASEAN Parliamentarians for Human Rights (APHR) till ambassaden inkommit med en ansökan om fortsatt stöd på 10 500 000 SEK för att genomföra sin Strategiska plan under perioden 1 januari 2019 till 31 December 2021. Insatsen syftar till att främja demokratisk utveckling och öka respekten för mänskliga rättigheter i Sydostasien, genom ökad kapacitet och förmåga hos parlamentariker och ex-parlamentariker i ASEAN- länderna att arbeta mot en öppnare, mer jämställd och hållbar region utifrån en rättighetsansats. Insatsen förväntas bidra till genomförandet av utvecklingsagendan 2030 genom att bredda kunskapen om mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och användning av rättighetsperspektivet inom parlamentariskt arbete. Insatsen kommer att genomföras mot länderna Brunei, Kambodja, Indonesien, Laos, Malaysien, Myanmar, Filipinerna, Singapore, Thailand, Timor-Leste, och Vietnam samt ASEAN som region.
Insatsen utgörs av ett känstöd till regionala MR- organisationen ASEAN Parliamentarians for Human Rights som är en icke-statlig, icke-vinstdrivande organisation med huvudkontor och registering i Jakarta. APHR har tagit emot kärnstöd från ambassaden sedan December 2014 och har under nuvarande avtalsperiod kunnat genomföra sitt arbete med god kvalitet samt har genom årlig rapportering till ambassaden kunnat redovisa och rapportera i enlighet med överenskomna resultat. Dessa resultat har validerats genom en utvärdering som genomfördes i juni 2018 och som bekräftar APHRs mervärde i regionen.
Enligt APHR's Strategiska Plan och ansökan till ambassaden kommer stödet att gå till finansiering APHRs kärnkostnader och genomförande av aktiviteter för att uppnå det övergripande målet "Parlamentariker i ASEAN - regionen främjar och skyddar demokrati, mänskliga rättigheter och en rättvis och hållbar utveckling i regionen". Detta mål uppnås genom underliggande mål; att parlamentariker aktivit samarbetar med civilsamhället i dessa frågor, att de strategiskt och konsekvent använder sin position som parlamentariker för att driva dessa frågor, samt att de samarbetar över nationella gränser inom ASEAN-regionen och i solidaritet. Aktiviteter kommer att genomföras inom området; utbildning och kapacitetsstärkande insatser, påverkansarbete, forskning och studier.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 ASEAN Parliamentarys for Human Rights (APHR) has to the Embassy submitted an application for continued core support of the amoun 10,500,000 SEK which will be used to implement their Strategic Plan during the period 1 January 2019 to 31 December 2021. The support aims to promote democratic development and enhance respect for human rights in Southeast Asia through increased capacity and ability of parliamentarians and ex-parliamentarians in the ASEAN countries to work towards a more open, more equitable and sustainable region based on a rights based approach. The initiative is expected to contribute to the implementation of the 2030 Development Agenda by broadening the knowledge of human rights, gender equality and the use of the rights perspective in parliamentary work. The support will be targeting the countries of Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Timor-Leste, and Vietnam, as well as ASEAN as a region.
The initiative is a support to the regional human rights organization, ASEAN Parliamentarians for Human Rights, a non-governmental non-profit organization with headquarters and registration in Jakarta. APHR has received core support from the embassy since December 2014 and has been able to carry out its work with good quality during the previous agreement period and has been able to deliver and report in accordance with agreed results through. These results have been validated through an evaluation conducted in June 2018, confirming APHR's added value in the region.
According to the APHR Strategic Plan and Application, the support will be funding APHR's core costs and implementation of core activities to achieve the overall goal "ASEAN parliamentarians promote and protect democracy, human rights and equitable and sustainable development in the region." This goal is achieved through the underlying goals; that parliamentarians actively cooperate with civil society on these issues, that they strategically and consistently use their position as parliamentarians to pursue these issues, and that they cooperate across national borders within the ASEAN region and in solidarity with each other. Activities will be carried out in the field of; education and capacity-building efforts, advocacy work and research.

title.narrative: Digital Rights Movement Building in Southeast Asia, 2019-2022
Digital Rights Movement Building in Southeast Asia, 2019-2022

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 EngageMedias projekt “Digital Rights and Video for Change: Building the Movement in Southeast Asia, 2019 - 2022” har ansökt om stöd från ambassaden med en budget på 13 140 000 SEK. EngageMedia är en ideell organisation för medier och teknik som arbetar för mänskliga rättigheter, miljö och social förändring tillsammans med rättighetsbärare inklusive människorättsförsvarare, journalister, oberoende filmskapare, tekniker, video- och digitala rättighetsaktivister, feminister, aktivister etc. Insatsen syftar till att stärka den digitala rättighetsrörelsen för att försvara det demokratiska utrymmet i Sydostasien. Under detta 3-åriga stöd kommer EngageMedias programområden att täcka:
• Kapacitetsbyggnad: ökad medvetenhet och påverkansarbete inom områdena digitala rättigheter, yttrandefrihet på nätet, dataskydd, säkerhet, utbildning av instruktörer i digitala rättigheter för regionala aktörer • Etablerande av nätverk: skapandet av regionala plattformar för media, politiska förespråkare, aktivister, sociala rörelser etc. där frågor om digitala rättigheter kan främjas • Forskning: de föreslagna ämnena för forskning är artificiell intelligens och hur AI påverkar mänskliga rättigheter, enskilda organisationers användning av öppen och säker teknik, krympande medborgerliga utrymmen samt integritet och övervakning. Resultaten kommer att användas för att bättre förstå dessa frågor och för att utveckla de mest effektiva strategierna för att bemöta dem. • Kommunikation och spridning av information och resultat: användning av video, film, multimedia och andra kreativa format för att öka medvetenheten hos allmänheten om mänskliga rättigheter, miljö och klimatförändringar, jämställdhet, ojämlikhet, fattigdomsminskning och korruption • Institutionell kapacitetsbyggnad: För att kunna ta itu med problemen ovan måste EngageMedia stärka sin organisationskapacitet. Därför kommer resultathantering, uppföljning och utvärdering (M&E) samt organisationens interna styrning och kontroll att vara en del av detta kärnstöd.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The EngageMedia’s program ‘Digital Rights and Video for Change: Building the Movement in Southeast Asia, 2019- 2022” has proposed the support to the Embassy with the budget of 13 140 000 SEK. EngageMedia is a media and technology non-profit organization working towards human rights, environment, and social change with rights holders including human rights defenders, journalists, independent film-makers, technologists, video and digital rights activists, feminists, campaigners, etc. The intervention aims to strengthen the digital rights movement to defend democratic space in Southeast Asia. Under this 3-year support, EngageMedia’s program areas will cover:
• Capacity building: awareness raising and advocacy on the areas of digital rights, online freedom of expression, data protection, security, training of trainers for regional actors on digital rights • Networking: convening regional platforms promoting digital rights issues with media, policy advocates, campaigners, social movement, etc. • Research: the proposed topics of research include Artificial Intelligence and its effects on human rights, CSOs’ use of open and secure technologies, shrinking civic spaces, and Privacy and Surveillance. The results will be used by policy advocates to better understand these issues and design the most effective advocacy approaches to them. • Communications and outreach: uses of video, film, multimedia, and other creative formats to raise awareness on human rights, environment and climate change, gender equality, inequality, poverty reduction, corruption to a wider public • Institutional building: to be able to address the issues above effectively, EngageMedia needs to be institutionally strengthened. Therefore the result management, M&E, and organizational and financial accountability will be part of this core support.

sector.narrative: Media and free flow of information

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.

16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.

17.6 - Enhance North-South, South-South and triangular regional and international cooperation on and access to science, technology and innovation and enhance knowledge-sharing on mutually agreed terms, including through improved coordination among existing mechanisms, in particular at the United Nations level, and through a global technology facilitation mechanism.

17.6 - Stärka nord–syd-samarbetet, syd–syd-samarbetet och det regionala och internationella trepartssamarbetet kring och tillgången till vetenskap, teknik och innovation samt öka kunskapsutbytet på gemensamt överenskomna villkor, inklusive genom förbättrad samordning mellan befintliga mekanismer, i synnerhet på FN-nivå, och genom en global mekanism för teknikfrämjande.

title.narrative: Supp Women's Civil Society in improving the inst. resp. to GBV in BiH 2018-2020"

description.narrative: Insatsen utgör ett fortsatt stöd till Kvinna till Kvinnas (KtK) och dess projekt "Supporting women's Civil Society in improving the Institutional response to Gender Based Violence (GBV) in Bosnia and Herzegovina" för perioden 2018-2020. KtK har under den senaste avtalsperioden genomfört ett pilotprojekt, perioden 2015-2017 som varat 2,5 år, som lagt en god grund och som haft goda initiala resultat. KtK och dess fyra partnerorganisationer (Lara Foundation, United Women, Centre of Women's Rights and TRIAL) i Bosnien och Herzegovina bygger nu vidare på de tidigare erfarenheterna och ska bidra till att ytterligare förbättra det institutionella gensvaret i kampen mot straffrihet för förövare av könsbaserat våld. Detta ska uppnås genom att stödja ovan angivna civilsamhällesorganisationer i BiH att bevaka och följa upp myndigheternas och rättsinstansernas följsamhet till nationell lagstiftning/lagar. Offrens rättigheter ska också bevakas utifrån behov av skydd och jämlik tillgång till rättvisa. Projektet kommer fortsatt stödja dessa 4 organisationer för att bevaka myndigheternas insatser för att bekämpa GBV, inklusive rättsprocesser i domstolar runt om i landet (monitoring teams gör detta), polisväsendet gensvar (i såväl Federationen som i RS) samt sociala instansers möjligheter till stöd för offren. Projektet vilar på en rättighetsbaserad inriktning (HRBA) med fokus på offren. KtK projekt har nära kopplingar till dels Sida stödda UN Women och dess GBV program (som har fokus på såväl offer som förövare/rehabilitering), samt till High Judicial Prosecution Council (HJPC) och det såkallade "Atlantic Initiative" som stödjer domar- och åklagarväsendet. Genom att arbeta med såväl rättsväsendet som med civila samhället bedöms ökar möjligheterna att uppnå positiva förändringar d.v.s. bättre skydd för vittnen, ökat fokus på offer, en stärkt kedja av omhändertagande av offer - från polisförhör till socialt skydd och domstolsutslag som ökar de utsattas rättigheter.

The contributionis a continuation of the previous support extended to KtK during 2015-2017. The aim of the project is to support local organisations in the fight against domestic violence and gender based violence in accordance with the Istanbul Convention (2013) which Bosnia and Herzegovina has ratified. The Project has a strong Component in its constant monitoring of Court cases where DV/GBV cases are brought forward.

The proposed Kvinna till Kvinna (Femdefenders) Project aims to strengthen women's rights in Bosnia and Herzegovina specifically with regards to victims of Gender Based Violence (GBV) enjoying adequate protection and access to justice. The scope of this programme aims both at 1) monitoring the response by law enforcement and judiciary and 2) advocate for an efficient system to protect victims of GBV and an improved penal policy for Domestic Violence (DV). The proposed amendment to the present agreement stand on two legs; one is only a continuation of the already on-going and implemented GBV/DV project which begun in 2018 and which was initially planned to end in December 2020. Due to the now suggested changes, and links to the Women Advisory Board (WAB) initiative, which is aiming for a fifteen months implementation the original project period is now suggested to end rather on 30th June 2021 - hence an extension with another six months. There is no any changes to the objective of the project in this part. Rather what could very briefly be mentioned is the fact that the GBV/DV project is even more relevant now given the outburst with COVID 19 (springtime of 2020) and where confinement enforced will lead to more pressure on women and girls and most likely will exacerbate the problem in question. The second leg ("Include Women in Change processes - Women's Advisory Board") of the amended agreement is hinged on the following: The overall objective of the programme us in support of the policy of the European Union towards BiH as follows: Ensure women's voices are represented in building sustainable peace and stability and helping the country to move beyond peace implementation towards European integration in the context of the EU Gender Action Plan facilitated by support of Sida and Kvinna till Kvinna. 3 Intermediate objectives have been identified those are the following:1) Target women of BiH engaged in political, economic and social processes in BiH are consulted on key issues on the current political agenda through the initiative and WAB. 2) EU engagement in BiH is informed by women's perspectives and attentive to gender issues. 3) Develop advocacy to promote women's perspective and inform EU officials.

sector.narrative: Ending violence against women and girls

tag.narrative: 5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

description.narrative: Narrative Report 2019 & Result Matrix and Risk matrix The overall results and some highlights of what KtK and its four partner organizations did during 2019 are presented below: A lot of work with legislative developments and where the adoption of amendments to the law on domestic violence in RS major achievement in the last year. This was made possible through lobby and advocacy work of partners and building capacities also within the relevant institutions in RS. The consolidation of Multi-Sector teams and their work in both entities also a major step, enabling improved legislative frameworks. Monitoring of court cases where DV cases been brought up another essential part of the work laid down by partners of KtK from all over BiH. The shadow report CEDAW crucial work and resulting in when BiH presented its report in November 2019 that the State need to engage better in protection, health and focus on needs of rural women. Free Legal Aid a big portion of work, helping 2528 women in the Federation and 2700 women in RS. United Women from Banja Luka has done qualitative analysis of court cases and did also hold round tables presenting its findings to wider audiences. KtK held network meetings in spring of 2019 inviting all their partners and which resulted in recommendations then issued to AGE. Two of KtK:s local partner organizations are involved in Safe houses provisions and support; LARA from Bijeljina (who has also worked during the year with Zenski Centar in Trebinje as one part). They provided protection to some 249 DV/GBV victims (women and children) and did some 1000 interventions. In all 18 persons were helped to safe houses, and 28 persons helped and assisted contacting people of trust. United Women from Banja Luka collected data about 329 cases (DV) in 2019, they also provided legal assistance and support to 283 women. UW invested efforts in trying to improve financing of safe houses in RS. RS law of free legal aid was one step ahead, did was made possible through the help and cooperation of women in politics in RS and through extensive lobby and advocacy from partner organizations. The EU accession process is closely followed, and where measures taken has linked to Council of Europe and Istanbul Convention hence steps in the right direction. The CWR organization and UWBL managed to arrive at and signed 32 protocols with 32 courts around the country to enable better monitoring of DV cases in all of BiH. However, in general the legal framework and the protection of women is not enough in BiH. There is need for more adequate and timely protection of women. One other observation done by TRIAL is the increased number of sexual violence against teenage girls observed. Deviations: following the Election in October 2018 there were substantive delays which meant less work done in 2019and even leading into 2020. Law protection in Federation slowed down one negative result but also in monitoring of court cases. The risk matrix is quite similar to previously indicated. There are some high risks however no one deemed severe (5 on a five graded scale). For all risks indicated KtK has suggestions to remedy the situation. COVID 19 seem not to constitute a risk on its own right, leading to not enable doing activities as planned by KtK in 2020. Financial Report 2019 & CSOs funding (separate report) The financial report for FY 2019 is clear and matching the original budget and budget lines presented by KtK previously. There is a clear and with the audit matched spending of 3.233.731 SEK during the year and resulting in a balance amounting to approx. 308.000 SEK which is to be used in the following year FY 2020. There is more or less under spending under nearly all assigned budget posts; the two overspending noticeable are I) approx. 2.500 SEK for field office in Sarajevo, and ii) approx. 2.000 SEK for conducting the audit. Both these minors’ costs are deemed reasonable and acceptable. The four organizations (local CSOs) who receive financial support for its GBV/DV related work is presented in a separate and useful table/matrix and were the financial spending during FY 2019 is clearly articulated in comparison with planned outlays. More or less 100% spending for all organizations are visible. Audit report 2019 & Management report The audit conducted shows no any anomality and is unqualified, as stipulated in the issued opinion by the auditor. It is noticed that a total of 3.233.731 SEK has been duly spend using Sida funds during the year. No and recommendations or negative observations comes from the 10 audit areas explored part of the audit of KtK in 2019. All on-channeling of funds to local CSOs has been conducted in a professional and correct way. There is no management letter issued by audit firm since no recommendations were issued. There is a short albeit management response presented by KtK based on the audit done for FY 2019. Since there were no any recommendations or observations made by the auditor (Grand Thornton) there is a short mentioning, there is nothing to observe nor to respond to given status identified. Comments and issues to raise during the Annual meeting 3rd June 2020 More general/generic questions to pose to Kvinna till Kvinna -General questions how has COVID 19/Corona affected you as an organization, the way you work and in relation to others? Delay and challenges FY 2020, both in terms your general GBV work but also implications for the WAB just agreed upon? extension? -Political situation in 2020 and onwards. Landscape of BiH? COVID and its wider implications for women, girls and other vulnerable groups and what it entail. What needs to be focus in coming strategies for us all: short term (next few months) and more long-term (2021- onwards). Safe houses issue, who to handle and tackle the best? -Coordination and collaboration with AGE/Gender Centers etc. Has working conditions in any way improved since Conference in April 2019. Exchange of information etc.? - RISKs and threats facing KtK and your local partners? Or possibilities. -What about your own funding situation? Outlook 2021 and onwards. Based on what strategies and documentations. Long-term plans for SUSTAINABILITY of KtK. Interested to talk about EXIT strategies. -A problem all along in our joint cooperation and collaboration has been linked to late reporting, delays and reminders which feels un-necessary and irritating. It seems that you might not have the right capacity to shoulder this responsibility. Your comments to this fact and plans to solve it. It is an issue of credibility. Financial and audit comments: -Both audit and financial reports shows no any cause of alarm. Clear and fine to both Controller and PO. 91% of funds used last year on-channeling to third parties (the four CSOs) reach 46% of total allocated funds, permitted level 55% so fine. Very little overspending in individual spenda seen in budget lines (less than 2%) good. And very little underutilization indicating good use and that money were in effect spent on actual planned activities in accordance with plans and budgets 2019. COVID might of course have wider implications for usage and the ability of KtK to conduct actives as earlier planned for during 2020. Need to follow up on these aspects.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: Narrative Report 2019 & Result Matrix and Risk matrix The overall results and some highlights of what KtK and its four partner organizations did during 2019 are presented below: A lot of work with legislative developments and where the adoption of amendments to the law on domestic violence in RS major achievement in the last year. This was made possible through lobby and advocacy work of partners and building capacities also within the relevant institutions in RS. The consolidation of Multi-Sector teams and their work in both entities also a major step, enabling improved legislative frameworks. Monitoring of court cases where DV cases been brought up another essential part of the work laid down by partners of KtK from all over BiH. The shadow report CEDAW crucial work and resulting in when BiH presented its report in November 2019 that the State need to engage better in protection, health and focus on needs of rural women. Free Legal Aid a big portion of work, helping 2528 women in the Federation and 2700 women in RS. United Women from Banja Luka has done qualitative analysis of court cases and did also hold round tables presenting its findings to wider audiences. KtK held network meetings in spring of 2019 inviting all their partners and which resulted in recommendations then issued to AGE. Two of KtK:s local partner organizations are involved in Safe houses provisions and support; LARA from Bijeljina (who has also worked during the year with Zenski Centar in Trebinje as one part). They provided protection to some 249 DV/GBV victims (women and children) and did some 1000 interventions. In all 18 persons were helped to safe houses, and 28 persons helped and assisted contacting people of trust. United Women from Banja Luka collected data about 329 cases (DV) in 2019, they also provided legal assistance and support to 283 women. UW invested efforts in trying to improve financing of safe houses in RS. RS law of free legal aid was one step ahead, did was made possible through the help and cooperation of women in politics in RS and through extensive lobby and advocacy from partner organizations. The EU accession process is closely followed, and where measures taken has linked to Council of Europe and Istanbul Convention hence steps in the right direction. The CWR organization and UWBL managed to arrive at and signed 32 protocols with 32 courts around the country to enable better monitoring of DV cases in all of BiH. However, in general the legal framework and the protection of women is not enough in BiH. There is need for more adequate and timely protection of women. One other observation done by TRIAL is the increased number of sexual violence against teenage girls observed. Deviations: following the Election in October 2018 there were substantive delays which meant less work done in 2019and even leading into 2020. Law protection in Federation slowed down one negative result but also in monitoring of court cases. The risk matrix is quite similar to previously indicated. There are some high risks however no one deemed severe (5 on a five graded scale). For all risks indicated KtK has suggestions to remedy the situation. COVID 19 seem not to constitute a risk on its own right, leading to not enable doing activities as planned by KtK in 2020. Financial Report 2019 & CSOs funding (separate report) The financial report for FY 2019 is clear and matching the original budget and budget lines presented by KtK previously. There is a clear and with the audit matched spending of 3.233.731 SEK during the year and resulting in a balance amounting to approx. 308.000 SEK which is to be used in the following year FY 2020. There is more or less under spending under nearly all assigned budget posts; the two overspending noticeable are I) approx. 2.500 SEK for field office in Sarajevo, and ii) approx. 2.000 SEK for conducting the audit. Both these minors’ costs are deemed reasonable and acceptable. The four organizations (local CSOs) who receive financial support for its GBV/DV related work is presented in a separate and useful table/matrix and were the financial spending during FY 2019 is clearly articulated in comparison with planned outlays. More or less 100% spending for all organizations are visible. Audit report 2019 & Management report The audit conducted shows no any anomality and is unqualified, as stipulated in the issued opinion by the auditor. It is noticed that a total of 3.233.731 SEK has been duly spend using Sida funds during the year. No and recommendations or negative observations comes from the 10 audit areas explored part of the audit of KtK in 2019. All on-channeling of funds to local CSOs has been conducted in a professional and correct way. There is no management letter issued by audit firm since no recommendations were issued. There is a short albeit management response presented by KtK based on the audit done for FY 2019. Since there were no any recommendations or observations made by the auditor (Grand Thornton) there is a short mentioning, there is nothing to observe nor to respond to given status identified. Comments and issues to raise during the Annual meeting 3rd June 2020 More general/generic questions to pose to Kvinna till Kvinna -General questions how has COVID 19/Corona affected you as an organization, the way you work and in relation to others? Delay and challenges FY 2020, both in terms your general GBV work but also implications for the WAB just agreed upon? extension? -Political situation in 2020 and onwards. Landscape of BiH? COVID and its wider implications for women, girls and other vulnerable groups and what it entail. What needs to be focus in coming strategies for us all: short term (next few months) and more long-term (2021- onwards). Safe houses issue, who to handle and tackle the best? -Coordination and collaboration with AGE/Gender Centers etc. Has working conditions in any way improved since Conference in April 2019. Exchange of information etc.? - RISKs and threats facing KtK and your local partners? Or possibilities. -What about your own funding situation? Outlook 2021 and onwards. Based on what strategies and documentations. Long-term plans for SUSTAINABILITY of KtK. Interested to talk about EXIT strategies. -A problem all along in our joint cooperation and collaboration has been linked to late reporting, delays and reminders which feels un-necessary and irritating. It seems that you might not have the right capacity to shoulder this responsibility. Your comments to this fact and plans to solve it. It is an issue of credibility. Financial and audit comments: -Both audit and financial reports shows no any cause of alarm. Clear and fine to both Controller and PO. 91% of funds used last year on-channeling to third parties (the four CSOs) reach 46% of total allocated funds, permitted level 55% so fine. Very little overspending in individual spenda seen in budget lines (less than 2%) good. And very little underutilization indicating good use and that money were in effect spent on actual planned activities in accordance with plans and budgets 2019. COVID might of course have wider implications for usage and the ability of KtK to conduct actives as earlier planned for during 2020. Need to follow up on these aspects.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: SALAR/SKR: Support decentralization in Ukraine Phase II
SKL: Stöd decentralisering i Ukraina fas II

description.narrative:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Swedish Association of Local Authorities and Regions (SALAR) has applied to Sida for funding of 41 710 000 SEK to carry out the "Support Decentralization in Ukraine Phase II Programme" in Ukraine during the activity period 2020 - 2022.
The intervention aims at strengthening democracy, improving governance and better service delivery to the citizens of Ukraine (women, men, boys and girls) by
1) supporting the Ministry of Education of Ukraine to implement improvements to the formula for allocating education grants (subventions) to sub-national governments by building the Ministry’s capacities in data collection, analysis and evidence-based decision-making (including transparency, openness, accountability, participation, fairness (non-discriminatory) and gender-responsiveness);
2) increasing capacity of the relevant state institutions (in particular Ministry of Community Development and Territories and Ministry of Finance) to analyze the financial data and use the financial data and analytics to inform policy;
3) supporting the Association of Amalgamated communities to become a stronger advocate for the interests of local communities and
4) providing relevant Parliamentary committees with important insights and knowledge particularly as it relates to issues of legislative processes, dialogue, transparency, accountability and gender responsiveness. The intervention builds upon the results and lessons of previous 5 years programme on the support to the reform of local self-governance in Ukraine.
The intervention’s total budget is 41 710 000 SEK, out of which approximately 900 000 SEK will be allocated for the programme evaluation (to be procured by the cooperation partner). Sida will be the only funder of the intervention.

title.narrative: Recovery and Peacebuilding in Eastern Ukraine
Återhämtning och fredsbyggande i östra Ukraina

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNDP har lämnat in en ansökan om finansiering om 33 MSEK för implementeringen av "Recovery and Peacebuilding Programme" i Donetsk och Lugansk oblasts under perioden 2018-2021.
Insatsen syftar till att nå en ny nivå av good governance och stärka medborgarnas engagemang för säkerheten i samhället; öka tillgången till rättsväsendets institutioner, miljöskydd samt juridiska tjänster hos den konfliktdrabbade befolkningen samt öka den sociala sammanhållningen. Projektet är organiserat under fyra huvudsakliga outputs (resultat) som ska nås genom att aktiviteter implementeras i 20 territoriella enheter (pilotenheterna), inklusive tolv nära kontaktlinjen. De fyra outputen (resultaten) är: 1) Starka, inkluderande och ansvarsfulla lokala styrningsinstitutioner bidrar till fredsbyggande och till att minska risker för konflikt 2) Ökad säkerhet i området; ett rättsväsende och juridiska tjänster som närmar sig folket i konfliktområden 3) Framgångsrikt decentraliserat miljöskydd som bygger på principer om deltagande och främjar en renare miljö i konfliktdrabbade områden 4) Sociala sammanhållningen stärks liksom medborgarnas inflytande på beslut som rör den lokala utvecklingen.
Insatsens totala budget uppgår till 129 MSEK där det svenska bidraget uppgår till 33 MSEK och det danska till 96 MSEK. Schweiz kommer att ansluta senare i processen.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 United Nations Development Organization (UNDP) has applied to the Swedish Embassy in Ukraine for funding of 33 million SEK to carry out the "Recovery and Peacebuilding Programme" in Donetsk and Lugansk oblasts during the period 2018-2021.
The intervention aims at attaining new levels of good governance and citizens engagement for accessible and quality community security, law enforcement, access to justice and environmental protection services, most relevant to the region’s conflict affected population, and increased social cohesion. The Project’s interventions are organised under 4 key outputs, to be achieved through activities that will be carried out in no less than 20 territorial units (the Project’s pilot territorial units), including 12 near the contact line. These outputs are: Output 1 – Capable, inclusive and accountable local governance institutions contribute to conflict risks mitigation and peacebuilding; Output 2 - Enhanced community security, law enforcement and access to justice services that are closer to the people in conflict affected areas; Output 3 - Successfully decentralised and participatory environmental protection promotes a cleaner environment in the conflict affected areas and Output 4 - Social cohesion and citizens’ influence on local development decisions strengthened.
The intervention’s total budget is 129 million SEK (12, 8 million USD), out of which Sweden will contribute 33 million SEK and Denmark will contribute approximately 96 million SEK (9.4 million USD). Switzerland will join later in the process, when the decision about its contribution is being taken.

The Project’s overall goal is to promote peace and stabilisation in eastern Ukraine through capable, inclusive, responsive and accountable regional and local governments and service providers. The key intended outcome of the Project is the attainment of new levels of good governance and citizens engagement for accessible and quality community security, law enforcement, access to justice and environmental protection services, most relevant to the region’s conflict affected population, and increased social cohesion. The Project’s outcome is in line with United Nations Partnership Framework (UNPF) 2018-2022 priorities and strategies focused on fulfilling the rights of the most marginalized and vulnerable populations in Ukraine, in particular with three of its strategic priorities (strategic pillars): Equitable access to quality and inclusive services & social protection (strategic pillar no 2), Democratic governance, rule of law and civic participation (strategic pillar no 3), Human security, social cohesion and recovery with a particular focus on eastern Ukraine (strategic pillar no 4). It is also in line with the national reforms and policies in the spheres of decentralisation, public administration reform, and reforms in the justice, law enforcement and security sectors. The Project approach builds on the core principle of “leaving no one behind”. It is particularly focused on SDG 11 (Sustainable Development of Cities and Communities), SDG 12 (Sustainable Consumption and Production), SDG 15 (Protect and Restore Terrestrial Ecosystems) and SDG 16 (Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions). SDGs detailed targets are provided in Section V - Results Framework. The Project’s interventions are organised under 4 key outputs, to be achieved through activities that will be carried out in no less than 20 territorial units (Project’s pilot territorial units), including 12 near the contact line: Output 1 – Capable, inclusive and accountable local governance institutions contribute to conflict risks mitigation and peacebuilding; output 2 - Enhanced community security, law enforcement and access to justice services that are closer to the people in conflict affected areas; output 3 - Successfully decentralised and participatory environmental protection promotes a cleaner environment in the conflict affected areas and output 4 - Social cohesion and citizens’ influence on local development decisions strengthened. Sweden has wished to softly earmark its funds for the Outputs 1 and 3.
